subject: RE: [junit] Help plz...
msgSnippet: ... I agree that you should strive to write code that does not need comments, however some times it is unavoidable. One prime example is where you are driven
messageBody:
> -----Original Message-----
> From: Ilja Preuss [mailto:preuss@...]
>
> Jim Dixon wrote:
>
> > Telling people that code should not be commented, that comments are
> > waste, remains extremely bad advice.
>
> This is true if you were only saying that.
>
> Saying "write your code in a way that it doesn't need
> comments" is very good advice, on the other hand. And in my
> experience you *can* learn to write code in a way that you
> very seldom need to fall back on this crutch.
>
> Just my two cents, Ilja

I agree that you should strive to write code that does not need
comments, however some times it is unavoidable. One prime example is
where you are driven to make a design decision that runs counter to
'common sense' and must indicate why in order to keep people from
wrongly rewriting the code in the future. This often happens when trying
to accommodate a framework or hardware that doesn't quite work as
advertised.
